ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith is an outstanding TF.Very available and knowledgeable on the subject.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was the only teaching assistant?
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was an amazing TA. She was always happy to help, review drafts, or answer questions. I honestly don't know if I would have done as well in this class if she hadn't been there. Thank you!
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith is an excellent lecturer. Her comments on our plan were very helpful.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was always accessible and well willing to offer help when it was needed. She was critical, but always with kindness and never harsh or condescending. We could not have completed our project without her.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was an excellent TF. Very committed to the class and student learning. Responsive to concerns, emails, and questions. She was great!

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was such an asset to our class. She was very accessible and made herself available to us constantly for feedback on our work, explanations of concepts, explanations of final project expectations, etc. She was also a good lecturer the weeks that Mark was out of town.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  She was like the boss of the class. Giving tough comments but also great help. I think we all couldn't have done it without her. And she was fast in grading and responding. One of the best TAs I've ever had.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was a dedicated, adept and kind teaching fellow. She was knowledgeable, available and very helpful throughout the class.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Martin was the ideal teaching assistant. She's extremely well-informed about silvicultural management; responds rapidly and patiently to questions; and her explanations are thorough yet easy to understand.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Very knowledgeable and responsive to questions. Grateful for help in walking around our property and good comments on our work.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This class is an excellent experience for students. It really allowed me to connect things that I learned in the classroom (both in this class and previous coursework) and apply it to a real world situation.
I came to this program because of this class and was not disappointed.

In response to the pace of class question, I feel that we might have pushed harder on our actual management plans towards the beginning of the semester. Had we started the sampling portion earlier, for example, the end of the project would likely have felt less rushed.

Mark is a committed educator and that was evident in the time he gave to this class. The workload was more than what would be two 3-credit courses, but I think that's just the nature of the project of developing a management plan.
I did not find the field trip to deed surveys helpful. Could have been done quicker, in class, or in New Haven and reduced travel time to the site.
This course was so much work but also so much learning. I wanted to curse the workload day in and day out but frankly I haven't learned more in one semester from any other course.

Question 13: Dr. Ashton clearly cares about his students and made it clear throughout the course that his ultimate goal is for this students to learn all aspects of writing a management plan so that we can work independently in the future.
One of the best courses I have taken at FES. Mark and Meredith both are incredible teachers, and the information is valuable for anyone dealing with land conservation.
Great course, very holistic and well-rounded. Mark and Meredith taught me a lot!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips and working through multiple drafts of the management plan
Fieldwork and field trips were extremely useful
It is the first class I have taken at FES with a practical project at its core. I learned so much in part because all the lectures and materials were geared towards its completion.
Group work, shared learning experiences, field trips to YMF w Mark and Meredith
Pulling together all the separate parts (history, tree ID, geology, silviculture, etc.) into a cohesive and useful product for the client.

Mark and Meredith cultivated an extraordinarily supportive classroom culture. This course was the most valuable one I've taken at FES, thanks to the high expectations for the quality of the final product and to the incomparable support offered along the way - from readings to lectures to field trips to team meetings with Mark and Meredith.
The landowners! Ours were so sweet. But also being able to be in the forest so much and finally being able to create a product that is actually needed and relevant.
Learning by doing. Being outside many weekends collecting data, learning to read the landscape and synthesizing this information for the management plan.
Great culmination of MF program. Integrates things from many courses well. Good practical experience that will have some use to our client.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I really didn't get anything out of the last third of the class where we would meet and get updates from each group. That seemed like a waste of time. I think that time could have been better spent by reviewing other peoples actual plans (to improve their plan, and get ideas for our own plan). It was nice to have the class time to ask Mark and Meredith questions, but aside from that, it didn't seem necessary.

This course takes up a huge amount of time. There are many field trips and field work. But toward the end of the class some of the seminar time was not organized. If we had known ahead of class that there was just going to be used for questions and there was no lecture. We could have used the time to work on our projects.
As I spoke of in a previous response, the timing felt slightly off when comparing the workload at the beginning and end of the semester.

Is it necessary to have an in-person mid-term exam and a mid-term take-home? It seems to add additional unnecessary work to what is already an extremely work-heavy course. The practice of both was helpful in the end, but maybe there are ways to pair these down?
Pace of lectures could be faster. More efficient group update/discussion time. Towards the end of the semester there was a lot of noodling around.
I though all aspects were good. Only input is about the deed workshop above.

Very extensive readings were posted most weeks, and it was sometimes difficult to gauge exactly how much of it we were expected to do - all of it, just whatever was useful to our team at that point, etc.
Time management? There was just too little time to do everything. Also, it is really not good that having a car in the team is the unofficial requirement of the course.

This course is notoriously heavy in terms of workload, but it is a necessary evil. Perhaps finding a way to help students start data-collection earlier in the semester would be helpful especially given the late start to the school year this fall.
I think we should have gotten to sampling earlier. Also, more time to work on management recommendations would be good.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: answered above

At times the lectures felt too expansive, past the knowledge we needed to accomplish our tasks. I felt this most towards the second half of the semester when we really just needed time to work and ask questions (I am thinking of the stakeholder analysis lecture, in particular).
Lectures were directly helpful in plan prep.
Yes - effective.
Yes, the course lectures effectively prepared us for field trips and for our individual team-based fieldwork.
There should have been quicker feedback (aka walks) on our initial soils assessments and stand delineations. Because we had to change both we had to add in sampling points etc.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I sort of wish that we had started sampling earlier in the semester, and had more time create a polished draft and solid presentation at the end. The work load was sort of inconsistent throughout the semester, and was almost too much to handle at the end. I almost wonder if this class should span two semesters (one class each semester) rather than having two classes during one semester.
Extremely important to the overall program. A must take course for foresters and environmental managers.

As a Master of Forestry candidate, this class served as the culminating capstone in many ways. Forest Stand Dynamics and Silviculture provided the necessary background for us to actually go out and read the landscape.
This was the best client-based course I've taken and I anticipate will be very applicable to future work.

My career plans are in private land conservation and landowner outreach, so this course was the perfect opportunity to build skills in landowner communication, deed surveying, parcel-level mapping, and fieldwork-based assessment and management planning for private land. My background is in environmental social science, so I was nervous that I would not be prepared for the physical science - based parts of the course - geology, hydrology, soils, species identification - but Mark and Meredith were incomparably supportive and helpful and ultimately I got out of this course exactly what I had hoped.
Well, that was probably one of the most important forestry skills. And I'll be able to use that during project work as well to determine baseline conditions.

This is really the capstone of the MF curriculum. It draws on all previous courses and brings them into a stand along product. It covers everything and allows foresters to really produce something with knowledge we have been learning over the program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It seemed like a good way to tie together many of the things I had previously learned, and provide good job preparation with a product that I could show off.
I want to do consulting so this course is very relevant.
Everyone I asked who had taken it said it was the best course they took at FES.
To gain hands on skills and a deeper understanding of forestry topics and applications.
See Question 20.
Such a basic forestry skill.
I had heard a lot about it and knew I would regret it if I didn't! It was a great learning opportunity to put boots on the ground and write a management plan.
Reputation and to fulfill MF requirements. Wanted to learn how to produce a management plan.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: My expectations were surpassed! I learned so much in this class that I will undoubtedly use in the future.
beyond
Absolutely yes, and more.

On one hand, I learned much more than I anticipated. On another, I wish there had been more information provided on how to develop management recommendations based on the information we had spent so long collecting. How does one prioritize management recommendations? Where does one go to find standards? We figured it all out but it was almost like there was a missing lecture on this topic of the work of actually writing management recommendations.
Yes.
Yes, see Question 20.
Exceeded them.
Absolutely.
It's a great course, taught by a great professor and TA. Helpful for anyone in land conservation.
Yes, very much so.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to have other people's expertise and experience to work off of. The only downside was trying to coordinate everyones schedule and find time to do work on the project.
Important to work as a group. Each person brought important skills to the team.

It offered the opporuinity to work together through drafts and ideas, and split up the labor. Each of us engaged in types of work that were unfamiliar, but we also could lead in the areas where we each felt strongest.
Shared learning- we all learned with and from each other. The comradery was great. Shared work load. I really enjoyed working with my group.
Group work was great. Fantastic how each of us came to together to do big lifts at different points in the project.
Learned from partners and made the class very enjoyable. No disadvantages.

The advantage was the opportunity to divide our heavy workload, often based on our group members' relative talents - GIS, timber inventory, graphic design, etc. The disadvantage was that it was often difficult to gauge whether the workload had been divided fairly - if our group had the opportunity to do it all over again, we might benefit from roughly dividing responsibilities at the very beginning of the course and then adapting as needed instead of deciding as we went along.

Some members of our group were not as committed as others which significantly shifted the workload and for these people there were essentially no repercussions. That is sad. But then again, great experience working with others.
We balanced each other's skills and personalities. Overall, we were able to learn from each other.
Huge project. Difficult to coordinate extensive field work at times, but you work around it.

Sometimes hard to divide up work well, but ultimately allowed us to pass the torch when each of us got very busy. Hard to produce such a big document in a team, but valuable to learn how to do so because that is how it's done in the real world.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Stay on top of the work! Write each section of the plan as early as you can (i.e. write the section on soils as soon as you go out and dig your soil pits) so that you remember everything and don't have as much work at the end of the course. However, just realize that no matter how much work you do in the beginning of the semester, there will be a huge crunch at the end of the semester to finish the project.
Be prepared to work very hard and come away with useful skills.
Don't overload on other courses! This class will be your main time expenditure.

It's a ton of work and you will be gone most weekends. BUT, if the subject matter is of interest and the process of developing a management plan seems like a helpful exercise to your future endeavors, this is a great opportunity.
Don't take this class if you are in a long distance relationship.

Definitely take it if you can - it is such a valuable experience and Mark and Meredith are so supportive. Also, think carefully about what skills you will bring to the table so that Mark and Meredith can match you with complementary team mates - it will make all the difference.
This course will eat up your life. DO NOT attempt to take 15 credits that semester in order to stay sane.
This course will be a significant part of your life and weekends. Do it only if you are willing to commit to doing a good job and engaging fully. Your groupmates are counting on you!
Take it. It's a down-to-earth, valuable course that's worth the time.
DO it! But know that it will be more time and work than the 2 classes worth of credits it is labelled as. You will learn a lot though and have fun doing it!
